attributes.title: Safety and Efficacy of anti-PD-1/anti-PD-L1 Therapy in Cancer Patients Living with HIV: A Systematic Review

q1.value: Safety and Efficacy of Anti-PD-1/Anti-PD-L1 Therapy in Cancer patients living with HIV：A Systematic Review

q2.value: Wenjiao Zhu, Yang Zhang, Aixin Li, Meixia Gao, Shui Jiang, Tong Zhang, Hao Wu, Xiaojie Huang, Guanzhi Chen

q3.value: In the era of antiretroviral therapy (ART) for HIV, people living with HIV remain at an increased risk of developing a range of cancers, cancer is a leading cause of death for the more than 37 million people worldwide living with HIV. Therapy that targets programmed death 1 or programmed death 1 ligand 1 (PD-1/PD-L1), which are known as immune checkpoints, has been recently rapidly developing as oncotherapy for various carcinomas. Immunotherapy may be beneficial for treating HIV-associated cancers; however, people living with HIV have been often excluded from cancer clinical trials that test novel agents. Herein, we conducted a systematic review of the literature to evaluate the safety and efficacy of anti-PD-1/anti-PD-L1 therapy in cancer patients living with HIV.

q4.value: Anti−PD-1 /anti-PD-L1 therapy would be safe and active in cancer patients living with HIV.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We identified studies published up to December 2019, through systematic literature searches and discussion with investigators. In this systematic review ,we performed a comprehensive database searching in PubMed, Web of Science, the Cochrane Library, and were done with medical subject headings and free text relating to “HIV”, “pembrolizumab”, “nivolumab”, “avelumab”, “atezolizumab”, and“durvalumab”.There are no research type restrictions on the studies we included.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
We identified studies that fit the criteria of describing cancer patients living with HIV who had been treated with anti-PD-1/anti-PD-L1. The excluded studies were wrong disease (no diagnosis of cancer), not involving HIV-positive patients, and not evaluating anti-PD-1/anti-PD-L1 therapy，review articles and non-English studies were excluded, too.
Two investigators (Wenjiao Zhu and Aixin Li) screened all titles and abstracts identified in the initial search and excluded studies in violation of the inclusion criteria. Two investigators (Wenjiao Zhu and Shui Jiang) assessed the full texts and data extraction. In cases of disagreement, consensus was achieved through referral to a third reviewer (Yang Zhang).

q13.value: We will analyze the data of 120 participants, age of participants ranged between 33 and 85.

question.value: Information from the included studies was extracted after review, including the name of the studies, publication year, inclusion/exclusion criteria, patient number, HIV load and CD4 cell count. Safety and tolerability were assessed using current NCI Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events. Immune-related adverse events grade 2 or higher were considered immune-related events of clinical interest (irECI). Tumor responses were evaluated using standard tumor-specific criteria, patients were categorized as responders to therapy if they achieved complete response, partial response, or stable disease. The safety of the treatment was measured by counting the number of adverse events and the efficacy of the therapy were measured through best response.
We used descriptive statistics to summarize the study findings. Statistical calculations were performed using Excel version 2019(16.0.12430.20112, Microsoft).

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

question2a.value: Resettlement years is the independent variable. It has 5 levels: less than 1 year; 1-3 years; 3-5 years; 5-10 years; more than 10 years. The experimental design is between-participants. The levels are exclusions for each other.

question2b.value: The dependent variable is the healthy level of lifestyle.

question3b.value: Annual household income and stress level are third variables that may influence the effect of resettlement years on healthy lifestyle.

question10b.value:
The researcher worked with the participant one-on-one. The researcher read out the questions and answer options in the Diabetes Risk Assessment questionnaire to the participant. The participant gave answers that best reflect their actual living status. 
The question on resettlement years and the section for Lifestyle Evaluation in the Assessment questionnaire is related to this research.
In the Lifestyle Evaluation section, the following questions will be asked to the participants:
1.	Do you miss meals or have long gaps between your meals during the day? If the participant answer “yes”, score 1 point; if “no”, score 0 point.
2.	How often do you eat fruits and vegetables? If the participant answer “everyday”, score 0 point; if “not every day”, score 2 point.
3.	Do you include at least 3 servings of fruits every day? If the participant answer “yes”, score 0 point; if “no”, score 1 point.
4.	Do vegerables take up ½(half) the space of your plate during each meal? If the participant answer “yes”, score 0 point; if “no”, score 1 point.
5.	Do you usually do some physical activity such as brisk walking for at least 30 minutes each day? If the participant answer “yes”, score 0 point; if “no”, score 1 point.
6.	Do you engage in muscle/bone strengthening using major muscle groups at least 2 days per week (weight, push-ups, yoga)? If the participant answer “yes”, score 0 point; if “no”, score 1 point.
7.	Do you consume Tobacco (e.g. smoking beedies, cigarette, hookah, small amount of tobacco wrapped in betel leaf etc.)? If the participant answer “yes”, score 1 point; if “no”, score 0 point.
The sum of the points was calculated, and the score reflects the healthy level of the participant’s lifestyle.

question4b.value: The subjects should be South Asian immigrants in GTA.

question5b.value: Data will be extracted from the data base of South Asian Diabetes Prevention Program in Flemingdon Health Centre. The Program has been assessing the risk of Type II diabetes for South Asian immigrants in GTA since 2004 using their Diabetes Risk Assessment questionnaire. Participants' answers for resettlement years and score for lifestyle evaluation in the assessment will be extracted for this research.

question6b.value: A meta-analysis of researches on resettlement years and refugee women living status indicated that the average η2 for the independent variable is 0.21 (Kingsbury and Chatfield, 2019), which gives an effect size f of 0.5. G*Power analysis output a sample size of 80 with 95% Power (see screenshot). Assuming a 6% attrition, the target sample size is 80*1.06=84.8~85.

question7b.value: The answers of the diabetes risk assessment questionnaire of the most recent 17 participants in each level of the resettlement years will be collected. The latest date of the assessment is February 25th, 2020.

question8b.value:
Data will be excluded when:
1) The participant's questionnaire is missing any of the answers for resettlement years, daily meal times, daily fruit consumption, vegetable portion in a meal,  frequency of physical activities, frequency of muscle strengthening activities or smoking habit.
2) The participant younger than 18 years old, because their lifestyle is most likely to be determined by their parents.
3) The participant is born in Canada
4) The participant's point for healthy lifestyle evaluation is more than 3*IQR from the rest of the scores in the group. According to BOXPLOT, scores beyond 3*IQR are considered extreme outlier.

question7c.value: Pairwise deletion will be used to handle missing data.

question8c.value: The scale of the score for healthy level of lifestyle is 0-8. All participants' result will fall into this scale.

question10c.value: There's an assumption that participants will answer the assessment questionnaire based on their reality. To avoid the violation of the assumption, the evaluator will remind the participants to answer the questions honestly to get the most accurate result of the assessment.

question1a.value: South Asian immigrants in GTA who have longer resettlement years would have a healthier lifestyle than new immigrants.

question5a.value:
South Asian immigrants in GTA are more susceptible to Type II diabetes and unhealthy lifestyle is the major cause of the disease (van Draanen et al. 2014). Therefore, it is important to investigate into the psychological barriers for South Asian immigrants in GTA to have a healthy lifestyle, so that healthcare professions could target those factors and help the population prevent diabetes and other health issues. 
People would start to care about living a healthy lifestyle only if there basic needs for survival are satisfied (Thorgeirsson and Kawachi, 2013). Because of the challenges that they face when resettling in an environment that is very different from home, South Asian immigrants in GTA would pay less attention on taking care of themselves their daily life. Therefore, it is hypothesized that the longer the resettlement years, the more likely the subjects would have a healthy lifestyle.

question1c.value:
Resettlement years is the independent variable, which groups the subjects into 5 levels: less than 1 year; 1-3 years; 3-5 years; 5-10 years; more than 10 years.
The score of the Lifestyle Evaluation section of the Diabetes Risk Assessment questionnaire is the operational definition of the healthy level of the participant’s lifestyle.

question2c.value: One-way ANOVA will be used to analyze the data.

question3c.value:
Resettlement years is the IV.
Healthy level of lifestyle is the DV.
The healthy level for daily meal times, daily fruit consumption, vegetable portion in a meal,  frequency of physical activities, frequency of muscle strengthening activities and smoking habit are the mediators. They define DV together.

attributes.title: The effect of labeling on memory in 7-month-old infants

q1.value: The effect of labeling on memory in 7-month-old infants

q2.value: Dana Michelle Chan, sandra waxman, Alexander Latourrette

q3.value: The types of labels that infants receive have conceptual consequences on how they construe objects as either individuals or members of a kind. Infants learn categories more efficiently when a set of discriminably different members of a category are named consistently with the same name, but they are also able to discriminate among these members of a category better when each is named with its own distinct name. One proposed mechanism for this set of findings is that consistent labels cue infants to pay attention to commonalities among exemplars while distinct labels highlight differences, allowing individual exemplars to stand out. In a previous study, 12-month-old infants were better at remembering distinct exemplars if each had been presented with distinct labels than with a consistent label. However, because we know that language facilitates categorization in infants as young as 3 months of age, we are interested in seeing if younger infants also take advantage of the differences between distinctly different vs shared names for a set of objects. Using a similar procedure as with 12-month-old infants, we will measure 7-month-old infants’ memory for the previously presented exemplars, asking whether this varies as a function of how they were named (with the same or with distinct names) during familiarization.

q4.value:
For Consistent Labels: If consistently-applied labels facilitate categorization by helping infants focus on commonalities among exemplars, then 7-month-old infants should have difficulty (perform at chance) distinguishing a previously seen exemplar and a new exemplar of the same category. This effect should be especially prominent on the first two trials of the test phase. 

If performance in the Consistent Label condition does not show this pattern and infants instead successfully remember individuals from familiarization, this will suggest that at 7 months, consistently-applied labels may benefit categorization by boosting attention to individual exemplars.

For Distinct Labels: If applying distinct labels to each exemplar highlights differences among the exemplars, then we hypothesize that 7-month-old infants should more readily distinguish a previously seen exemplar and a new exemplar of the same category.  As a result, we predict greater looking towards a new object of the same category versus a previously seen exemplar (in other words, a novelty preference). This effect should be especially prominent on the first two trials of the test phase. 

Lastly, we also hypothesize that novelty preference scores between the two conditions (Consistent Labels VS Distinct Labels) will be different, indicating a significant effect of condition on infants’ memory for the individual exemplars. This effect should be especially prominent on the first two trials of the test phase. 

If performance in both conditions is at chance, this may suggest that the task is too difficult for the younger infants. However, if we observe novelty preferences in both conditions, this will suggest that labels promote categorization by enhancing attention to the exemplars.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Video coders are blind to the condition.

question.value: We have a between-subjects design with one factor (Labeling Condition) with two levels (Consistent Labels and Distinct Labels).

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: We will be recruiting infants from a database of families from the greater Chicago area who previously indicated interest in participating in our studies. Infants must be 7.0 to 8.5 months of age at the time of participation, were born full-term, and must not have more than 45% exposure to a language other than English. Parents of participants will be offered either a book and a t-shirt or $10 for their child’s participation.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 24 participants for each of the four test trials in both Consistent Label and Distinct Label conditions. To account for infants missing trials, we will run additional infants beyond 24 per condition until all test trials contain at least 24 observations.

question.value: We manipulated the type of labels that infants will receive during the familiarization phase. Infants will hear either consistent labels, where all of the exemplars will be given the same novel label, or distinct labels, where each exemplar will have its own unique novel label.

Each infant will be presented with a series of four images of cartoon-like animals on alternating sides of a screen in the familiarization phase. At test, infants will view four test trials, each featuring two images of animals presented side-by-side. One image will be familiar (seen previously during the familiarization phase) and the other will be novel. We will measure infants’ looking to each test image. More specifically, we will compute a novelty preference score (looking at the novel image/looking at both images) for each test trial.

To test our first two hypotheses (i.e. chance looking for Consistent Labels and novelty preference for Distinct Labels), we will conduct t-tests against chance for each test trial in both conditions. 
	
To test for differences between the Consistent Label and the Distinct Label conditions, we will use t-tests to compare looking times between the two conditions for each of the four test trials.

To analyze the looking time trajectory over test trials, we will conduct a growth curve model with trial and condition as fixed effects and participants as a random effect.

q20.value: Proportion looking towards the novel exemplar will be logit-transformed.

q22.value: To be included for analysis, infants must contribute at least 3 test trials on which they (1) look for a minimum of 5 seconds at the familiar exemplar during the familiarization phase, (2) look at both exemplars presented during the test trial, and (3) look for a minimum of 5 seconds on the test trial.

q24.value: We expect that age may be related to how well infants can encode and use the labels they are presented with. Therefore, we will also look for a possible interaction between age and condition.

attributes.title: Acupuncture for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS): an overview of systematic reviews and meta-analyses protocol
attributes.description: This overview of systematic reviews (SRs) and meta-analyses will aim to critically appraise the methodology and reporting quality of the relevant SRs and meta-analyses with the aim of identifying whether acupuncture could provide an effective treatment for patients with PCOS or not.

q1.value: Acupuncture for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS): an overview of systematic reviews and meta-analyses protocol

q2.value: Xiaohua Chen, Huaying Fan, Jiao Chen, Ping wu, Huayu Fan

q3.value: As the results of previous systematic reviews and meta-analyses on acupuncture for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) have provided inconsistent evidence. This overview of systematic reviews (SRs) and meta-analyses will aim to critically appraise the methodology and reporting quality of the relevant SRs and meta-analyses with the aim of identifying whether acupuncture could provide an effective treatment for patients with PCOS or not.

q4.value:
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is one of the most common cause of anovulatory infertility conditions in clinic, which is characterized by ovulatory dysfunction, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries.It is estimated that PCOS prevalence has varied from 5% to 15% among women of reproductive age. PCOS can result in profound, long-term physical and mental health consequences. In addition to anovulatory infertility, women suffering from PCOS have an increased risk of miscarriage, pregnancy complications and metabolic abnormalities such as obesity, hypertension, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.The cause of PCOS is genetic related,and environmental factors such as prenatal exposure to androgens may also play a role in the etiology of PCOS.
Currently, pharmacological therapies for PCOS include clomiphene, which is considered as the first-line treatment to induce ovulation in women with PCOS.However, clomiphene turned out to have a high failure rate of without ovulation, a relatively low cumulative live birth rate, and a high multiple-pregnancy rate.Other pharmacological  treatments such as oral contraceptives are used , but it is reported that long-term use of oral contraceptives in women with PCOS may lead to the development of obesity and metabolic abnormalities.  Given the fact that clomiphene and oral contraceptives have some side effects during the treatment of PCOS, alternative therapies have become an important supplement for PCOS treatment, among which acupuncture has played an important role. Acupuncture, as an integral part of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM), has gained increased popularity in clinical treatment of PCOS. Although the efficacy of acupuncture for treating PCOS has been proved in clinical practice, some researchers suggest that acupuncture works through placebo effect instead of its real therapeutic effect.Several SRs were carried out to investigate the effect of acupuncture on PCOS, yet gaining inconsistent conclusions. Therefore, it is necessary for us to undertake an overview of SRs and meta-analyses to evaluate the methodology and reporting quality of the SRs and meta-analyses.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Electronic databases including MEDLINE via Ovid, EMBASE, PubMed, Cochrane library, China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), Chinese Scientific Journal Database (VIP database), and Wanfang Database will be searched for related SRs and meta-analyses from inceptions to the search date without language restrictions. Two reviewers will independently select SRs and meta-analyses and collect related data, and a third reviewer will be introduced if any disagreement happened during the assessing. The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) and the latest Assessment of Multiple Systematic Reviews 2 (AMSTAR2) checklists will be employed to evaluate the reporting and methodology quality.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Two reviewers will respectively screen the study titles and abstracts to identify potentially eligible SRs and meta-analyses according to the inclusion criteria. The full texts reviews will be obtained and independently screened before final inclusion. If a disagreement on the inclusion of a review cannot be resolved, a third reviewer will make the final decision after discussion.
Two reviewers  will independently extract the data of all eligible SRs and meta-analyses by employing the specially designed extraction forms. The following items will be included in the data extraction form: first author, year of publication, country, number of RCTs enrolled, quality assessment tool for RCTs, and characteristics of interventions in control and treatment groups, outcome measures, data synthesis methods, main results, and conclusions. The final extracted data will be cross-checked by the two extractors, and any disagreement regarding the extracted data will be discussed with and adjudicated by a third reviewer  . If any data are insufficient or unclear, the first or corresponding author for the study concerned will be contacted via e-mail or telephone to provide additional information.

q13.value: There are no size requirements for this study. Several systematic reviews will be included.

question.value: The primary outcomes of this overview will be ovulation induction. Secondary outcomes will be LH/FSH, menstrual frequency, birth live, pregnancy, conception, biochemical assessments, anthropometry. Adverse events such as acupuncture fainting, needle twisting and breaking, bleeding and organ injury will also be taken into account as safety measurement.

The assessment of Multiple Systematic Reviews 2 (AMSTAR2) will be utilized to assess methodological qualities of the included SRs and meta-analyses. AMSTAR is a quality assessment tool for critically assessing the quality of RCTs, while AMSTAR2, which is an update of AMSTAR, can be used to appraise SRs  and meta-analyses of intervention trials including both RCTs and non-RCTs.[21] There are 16 items in AMSTAR2. Items 2,4,7,9,11,13 and 15 are consider to be more critical than other items, which may affect the production of the systematic review and the validity of the results. The main rule for rating overall quality in the results of SRs and meta-analyses as follows: SRs and meta-analyses with no or one noncritical weakness will be rated as high; with more than one noncritical weakness will be rated as moderated; with one critical flaw with or without noncritical weakness will be rated as low; with more than one critical flaw with or without noncritical weakness will be rated as critically low. 
Two reviewers will independently assess the methodological quality of each included SR and meta-analysis by employing the AMSTAR2. Any disagreement during the assessment will be discussed or solved by a third reviewer.
Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) will be applied to evaluate the report quality of included SRs and meta-analyses. There are 27 items used to assess whether the reports are standardized or not. Discussion and a third reviewer will be introduced when confronted with disagreement during the assessing process.

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is one of the most common cause of anovulatory infertility conditions in clinic, which is characterized by ovulatory dysfunction, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries.It is estimated that PCOS prevalence has varied from 5% to 15% among women of reproductive age. PCOS can result in profound, long-term physical and mental health consequences. In addition to anovulatory infertility, women suffering from PCOS have an increased risk of miscarriage, pregnancy complications and metabolic abnormalities such as obesity, hypertension, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.The cause of PCOS is genetic related,and environmental factors such as prenatal exposure to androgens may also play a role in the etiology of PCOS.
Currently, pharmacological therapies for PCOS include clomiphene, which is considered as the first-line treatment to induce ovulation in women with PCOS.However, clomiphene turned out to have a high failure rate of without ovulation, a relatively low cumulative live birth rate, and a high multiple-pregnancy rate.Other pharmacological  treatments such as oral contraceptives are used , but it is reported that long-term use of oral contraceptives in women with PCOS may lead to the development of obesity and metabolic abnormalities. Acupuncture, as an integral part of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM), has gained increased popularity in clinical treatment of PCOS. Although the efficacy of acupuncture for treating PCOS has been proved in clinical practice, some researchers suggest that acupuncture works through placebo effect instead of its real therapeutic effect.Several SRs were carried out to investigate the effect of acupuncture on PCOS, yet gaining inconsistent conclusions. attributes.title: Broker Accountability and Candidate Selection
attributes.description:
Clientelist brokers are often caught between two informal sources account-
ability: politicians and voters. Recent advances in the literature on clien-
telism have shown that the degree to which brokers are accountability to
everyday people can impact the ability of voters to extract bene?ts from
the state (Auerbach, 2016; Gottlieb, 2017; Nathan, 2019). I present a re-
search design to be ?elded in March and April of 20201 that tests the e?ects
of bottom-up broker accountability on a broker's candidate choice. Taking
advantage of upcoming elections for neighborhood association presidents,
who are the de facto community brokers in many parts of Colombia, I col-
lect unique data on bottom-up broker accountability, including re-election
rates, margins of victory, and voter participation. This observational data
is joined with in-depth broker interviews and a discrete-choice experiment
that allows us to see with greater precision how brokers facing di?erent
accountability constraints choose candidates to work with. I expect that
bottom-up accountability impacts both the extent of rent-seeking behav-
ior and the permissiveness of undesirable candidate traits like allegations of
corruption.

q3.value: Clientelist brokers are often caught between two informal sources accountability: politicians and voters. Recent advances in the literature on clientelism have shown that the degree to which brokers are accountability to everyday people can impact the ability of voters to extract benefits from the state (auerbach 2016, gottlieb 2017, nathan 2019) I present a research design to be fielded in March and April of 2020 that tests the effects of bottom-up broker accountability on a broker's candidate choice. Taking advantage of upcoming elections for neighborhood association presidents, who are the de facto community brokers in many parts of Colombia, I collect unique data on bottom-up broker accountability, including re-election rates, margins of victory, and voter participation. This observational data is joined with in-depth broker interviews and a discrete-choice experiment that allows us to see with greater precision how brokers facing different accountability constraints choose candidates to work with. I expect that bottom-up accountability impacts both the extent of rent-seeking behavior and the permissiveness of undesirable candidate traits like allegations of corruption.

q4.value:
1: Brokers facing competitive elections will be more likely to favor candidates that offer public benefits for the neighborhood over candidates offering personal benefits.
2a: Brokers facing competitive elections will be more permissive of undesirable candidate traits.
2b: Brokers facing competitive elections will be less permissive of undesirable candidate traits.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is being conducted with communal action board leaders in the city of Santa Marta, Colombia. I am running a conjoint experiment where subjects choose between two candidates that vary on key characteristics. Research subjects will be shown 6 pairs of candidates in the experiment. While the candidate profiles are randomized, the primary quantity of interest is the difference in sub-group responses - leaders facing competitive elections this April, and leaders facing non-competitive elections. The study will also collect a wealth of descriptive data about these local leaders and includes an in-depth interview about their experience as a local leader. I will collect data about the competitiveness of the elections using multiple indicators. I have a self-described measure of competitiveness where I ask local leaders if they think they will have an opponent at the time of the conjoint experiment. I match this data with actual election results that will show turnout percentages, margin of victory, and whether the president faced an opposition candidate.

q9.value: The conjoint experiment utilizes randomization in candidate profile attributes in each pair and randomization of the order in which the attributes are displayed between subjects. The independent variable in the study - the level of competition research subjects are facing in an upcoming election,  cannot be randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: My enumerators began enumerating the survey on March 2nd, and I made some small tweaks to the protocol based on the feedback from my enumerators. Research subjects in the study wanted an opportunity to do the interview portion, which was originally only assigned to 1/3 of the sample, so I changed the protocol to allow for voluntary option into the interview category for the remaining 2/3. Most importantly, we moved from randomly sampling city grids to snowball sampling because, first, our research subjects were often not available at home (due to their upcoming elections), and second, my male enumerator was not able to readily get information on where neighborhood leaders lived because the recent violence against neighborhood leaders in Colombia has made residents wary of outsiders.

question.value:
The study population is local neighborhood leaders (Presidents or vice presidents of Juntas de Acción Comunal) in the urban part of Santa Marta (including the corregimientos of Bonda and Taganga). Subject recruitment is done by snowball sampling using starting points that I collected at pre-election training events for local leaders. The human subjects data collection period will be during March and April 2020, and will end four days prior to the election date for local leader elections (April 26). The elections results will be collected in May and June of 2020, or as soon as they are made publicly available by the city of Santa Marta. 

My enumerators include three college seniors who live in the area of the survey and as such are familiar with the area and the local dialect. They will contact participants over the phone to schedule a time and meeting place to conduct the surveys and interviews with the subjects. Most of the time, enumerators will travel to the home of local leaders or the neighborhood community center, but will also meet subjects in other locations as the need arises. 

Data will be collected using qualtrics offline surveys on tablets and audio recorders if subjects agree to be recorded, or paper notes if subjects do not agree to be recorded.

q13.value: The study will attempt to include the entire population (208), but I expect that the study team will be able to include 150 local leaders due to time constraints, scheduling difficulties and safety concerns. Since the enumerators for the survey will be travelling to conduct the interviews alone, we may exclude some neighborhoods due to security concerns as issues arise (and the protocol will be edited to reflect that).

q14.value:
My budget allowed me to hire three enumerators. At a rate of 2-3 interviews a day between March and April, excluding Saturdays and Sundays, I expect that they can interview no more than 200. 

Human subjects data collection must conclude prior to the local neighborhood elections on April 26th because the competitiveness of the upcoming election is a critical variable in the research design. Carnaval prevented us from being able to start the survey collection until the first week of March and many people will be gone for Holy Week the second week of April. 

As such, while we will attempt to survey all of the local leaders, I expect that we will sample 150.

q15.value: We will terminate the data collection four days before the April 26th local leader elections or when all of the subject population has been invited to participate in the study.

question.value:
The outcome measures will be the marginal effect of each attribute in the conjoint experiment on the likelihood that a candidate with that attribute level will be chosen as the preferred candidate (holding all other attributes at their neutral category).  
The quantity of interest will be the interaction between the level of competition that the subject faces in the upcoming election and the marginal effect of each attribute. 
The level of competition will be measured multiple ways. Two measures will be self-described - subjects will be asked if they know of a competitor facing them in the upcoming election (yes, no, unsure) and will be asked if they believe they will win the election (yes, no, unsure). I will then collect information from the mayor's office about the results of the elections on April 26. I will collect information on how many people voted in the election, how many were eligible, whether the subject faced opposition, whether he or she won, and the margin of victory. I will create an index for competition by combining these data points, however since the availability of elections results data is expected but not guaranteed, I expect that this portion of the research design may change.

Because the outcome in a discrete-choice experiment with two choices is binary, I will analyze the results using a logistic regression with dummy variables for each attribute and interaction effects between the level of competition and the attributes of interest. Each observation is a candidate profile shown to a respondent in the experiment, leading to 1,800 total candidates. The coefficient on each attribute variable represents the average marginal component effect or the average effect of the attribute on the probability that the candidate is chosen compared to the baseline neutral level for that attribute (Hainmueller et al., 2014). 

I will also run the same logistic regression without the interaction with competitiveness levels to describe the marginal component effect of each attribute for the sample overall. 

To test hypothesis 2, I will run additional models with interaction effects between the corruption attribute, the experience attribute, and the income attribute with other attributes for the candidate to understand how combinations of candidate attributes affect the likelihood that a candidate is chosen by brokers.  

For robustness checks, I will run the same regression with dummy variables for the ordering of the candidate pairs and interactions between the order of the pairing and each attribute. 

Because this is a small sample (n=150) I plan to use block bootstrapping (repeated sampling from respondents) to calculate standard errors.

q20.value: The level of competitiveness of the local leader elections will become a binary variable (more competitive, less competitive). Since I am unaware of data availability, I will edit the registration to reflect competitiveness coding.

q22.value: All valid responses will be recorded. By valid I mean, the correct person was interviewed and the interview was completed following protocol.

q23.value: If the subject does not complete the 6 pairs of candidate choices or the block on election competitiveness, the subject will be excluded.

q24.value: Different levels of experience as a social leader, gender, and neighborhood economic status, may affect the marginal effects of certain attributes in the experience.

q1.value: Examining Daily Experiences in STEM and Non-STEM Workplaces Through the Lens of Self-Determination Theory

q3.value: This project is intended to provide evidence of valid measurement and theoretical grounding for examining differences in STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) and non-STEM workplace experiences of men and women. We plan to investigate the relationships between the key elements of self-determination theory and job satisfaction.

q4.value:
There will be a significant interaction between STEM-status (STEM vs non-STEM) and gender on job outcomes (job satisfaction, intent to leave job, intent to leave line of work, and career commitment).

We expect that basic psychological need satisfaction and frustration will mediate the relationship between STEM-status and job outcomes differently for men and women.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is a quasi-experimental 2x2 design. Participants will indicate whether they perceive themselves as working in a STEM or non-STEM field and whether they are male or female.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The investigators who will be analyzing the data have agreed to withhold from doing so until preregistration of the data is complete.

question.value: A total of 1,000 participants (250 STEM women, 250 STEM men, 250 non-STEM women, and 250 non-STEM men) will be recruited via Qualtrics participant panel, an online survey platform that recruits participants according to researchers' specifications.

q13.value: We planned to recruit about 1,000 participants, with equal numbers of women and men who work in STEM and women and men who work in non-STEM

q14.value: This was the maximum sample we could receive with our budget.

q15.value: Data collection was terminated when we received about 1,000 participants.

question.value: All relevant variables and how we will measure them and form composites are included in the attached document.
All relevant variables and how we will measure them and form composites are included in the attached document.

We will use factorial ANOVA to test our lower order hypothesis: interaction between STEM status and gender on job outcomes (job satisfaction, career commitment, intent to leave job, and intent to leave organization). Significant interactions will be examined further with simple effect analyses.

We will conduct a moderated mediation to examine whether basic psychological needs satisfaction and frustration mediate the relationship between STEM-status and  job outcomes differently for men and women.

q21.value: We will be using two-tailed tests for all analyses and a p-value of .05 to determine statistical significance

q22.value: If a participant fails multiple attention checks in the study, they will be excluded from this study.  Multivariate outliers will be excluded from all analyses. Univariate outliers on a particular scale will be excluded only from analyses using that particular scale.

q23.value: If participants skip more than 20% of the scale, we will remove them from analysis. If they completed at least 80% of the scale we will include them in analysis by averaging their answered scores to form a composite.

registration_responses.q21: We will be using two-tailed tests for all analyses and a p-value of .05 to determine statistical significance
registration_responses.q22: If a participant fails multiple attention checks in the study, they will be excluded from this study.  Multivariate outliers will be excluded from all analyses. Univariate outliers on a particular scale will be excluded only from analyses using that particular scale.
registration_responses.q23: If participants skip more than 20% of the scale, we will remove them from analysis. If they completed at least 80% of the scale we will include them in analysis by averaging their answered scores to form a composite.
registration_responses.q8.question: This study is a quasi-experimental 2x2 design. Participants will indicate whether they perceive themselves as working in a STEM or non-STEM field and whether they are male or female.
registration_responses.q12.question: A total of 1,000 participants (250 STEM women, 250 STEM men, 250 non-STEM women, and 250 non-STEM men) will be recruited via Qualtrics participant panel, an online survey platform that recruits participants according to researchers' specifications.
registration_responses.q17.question: All relevant variables and how we will measure them and form composites are included in the attached document.
registration_responses.q18.question: All relevant variables and how we will measure them and form composites are included in the attached document.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use factorial ANOVA to test our lower order hypothesis: interaction between STEM status and gender on job outcomes (job satisfaction, career commitment, intent to leave job, and intent to leave organization). Significant interactions will be examined further with simple effect analyses.

We will conduct a moderated mediation to examine whether basic psychological needs satisfaction and frustration mediate the relationship between STEM-status and  job outcomes differently for men and women.

q3.value:
The lack of women in leadership remains a puzzle. Years of research unpacking how women ascend into leadership points to numerous barriers (a labyrinth) designed to keep them out; however new evidence suggests this is changing.  Women who are high performing (capable of advancing into the upper echelons) seem to be in high demand. In fact, companies that value diversity are even willing to pay them more than equally performing men. However, attracting or keeping such women may be an issue. This presents a problem to organizations as turnover among high performing employees is costly. It also may slow female ascension into the upper ranks, as companies are more likely to internally (as opposed to externally) promote a woman to top management. Both of these undermine progress towards closing the gender-gap in top leadership positions.

In this study, we test one viable and ethical solution. A company may be more likely to keep high performing women when their immediate supervisor is also a woman. Furthermore, we seek to examine the underlying mechanism of this phenomena. That is, why a female supervisor is a powerful signal to other high performing women. We introduce (and test) a construct called a drafting signal (akin to drafting in professional cycling) - the extent to which women believe gender-specific barriers to advancement have been mitigated by prevailing female leaders.

(For citations please see the end of this registration)

q4.value:
Two way Interaction: Gender moderates the negative relationship between performance and turnover intentions, such that it is stronger for men than women.

Two way Interaction: Gender moderates the negative relationship between performance and job search behaviors, such that it is stronger for men than women.

Three way Interaction: For female subordinates, a supervisor's gender moderates the relationship between performance and turnover intentions, such that the negative relationship between performance and turnover intentions is stronger for female subordinates with a female supervisor than for female subordinates with a male supervisor.

Three way Interaction: For female subordinates, a supervisor's gender moderates the relationship between performance and job search behaviors, such that the negative relationship between performance and job search behaviors is stronger for female subordinates with a female supervisor than for female subordinates with a male supervisor.

Moderated, moderated-mediation: Supervisor gender and subordinate gender will  moderate the indirect effect of performance on turnover intentions/job search behaviors through drafting, such that the indirect effect will be greater when supervisor gender is female and subordinate gender is female.

Moderated-mediation: Supervisor gender will moderate the indirect effect of subordinate gender on turnover intentions/job search behaviors through drafting, such that the indirect effect will be greater when supervisor gender is female.

Three-way interaction: For female subordinates, a supervisor's gender moderates the relationship between performance and drafting, such that the positive relationship between performance and drafting is stronger for female subordinates with a female supervisor than for other pairings.

Correlations: Looking at how drafting correlates with gender (supervisor and subordinate...we predict the correlation will be stronger for female subordinates and female supervisors), outcome variables and other new control variables such as social support, diversity climate, job satisfaction and information sharing.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cross-sectional, survey design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through MTurk. Participants will be paid $1 for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 18 years old, employed full-time, work in the U.S. and have a supervisor (or equivalent).

q13.value: Our target sample size is 1,000-2,000 participants. Reasonable gender (and pairing) representation.

q14.value: We used the software program R (pwr package, pwr.f2.test) to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power at the standard .05 alpha error probability to detect an effect size based on actual results from our previous study. We used an effect size of .004 (calculated as the change in R-squared as a means of evaluating the impact of the three-way interaction above and beyond the other predictors in the model) from our previous study to determine we needed over 1,900 participants to detect this effect.

question.value: Please see the attached document "Measured Variables 2" with the full list of our variables.
In most cases of our measured variables we take the mean of the questions / statements that are included in that scale, pending adequate reliability and validity.

We will use multiple regression to test our hypotheses. We will also use the Process Macro in SPSS to test our moderated mediation hypotheses. We will also use Stata to test moderated mediation hypotheses, using bootstrapping (10,000 repetitions) as well as confirmatory factor analyses.

q20.value: Women will be coded as 1 and Men will be coded as 0.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for evaluating our hypotheses.

q22.value: We will drop responses that fail the manipulation check. Outliers will be included, unless they are extreme (we will disclose this if outliers are dropped). We will also exclude non-binary or self-described genders for the purposes of this research.

q23.value: In this study, subjects will be required to answer all of the necessary questions. However, there may be missing demographic information. In this case, if a demographic variable is important to the analysis (as a control), they will not be including if the information is missing.

attributes.title: Understanding the Effects of Legal Electrification: Evidence from a Regression Discontinuity Design

q1.value: Understanding the Effects of Legal Electrification: Evidence from a Regression Discontinuity Design

q2.value: S.P. Harish | Ryan Kennedy | Daniel Thomas

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This is a pre-analysis plan for a quasi-experimental project analyzing the relationship between the legality of electrical connections and several outcome variables in India. We exploit a law that creates a discontinuity in the likelihood that a household has a legal electricity connection: households more than 40 meters beyond the radius of power poles are not eligible for electricity connections. By using the 40 meter line as an exogenous factor affecting the likelihood of electrification, we are able to causally identify a wide-range of impacts of legal electrification. Electricity theft is an issue in many developing countries \citep{depuru2011electricity}. Moreover, electricity theft is increasing globally \citep{smith2004electricity}. Electricity theft can cause significant negative effects: it can overload the generation unit, damage appliances, and cause brownouts and blackouts at peak load \citep{depuru2011electricity}. It also leads to efficiency losses, as the distribution system requires greater maintenance \citep{tasdoven2012improving}. In India, line losses, or electricity that is received by power stations for distribution but never billed for, are large: \citet{min2014electoral} show that in Mahamaya Nagar, half of power distributed was not billed. However, there is great variation in line losses throughout Uttar Pradesh, the state in which they collect data. The large amount of illegal electricity connections in India leads us to formulate our main research question: how does legal electrification affect the daily lives of electricity consumers? To answer this research question, we propose new hypotheses toward understanding the relationship between legal electricity connections and outcomes affecting the lives of electricity consumers. Generally, we focus on seven areas of outcomes: expenditures, kerosene usage, artificial lighting, appliances, household activities, satisfaction and attitudes, and general knowledge. The construction of these variables and the specific hypotheses tested are outlined below.

q16.value: We now specify our hypotheses and the testing of them. \subsubsection{Expenditures} We test the effect of legal electrification on five expenditure outcome variables, \textit{Total Expenditure}, \textit{Kerosene Expenditure}, \textit{Electricity Expenditure}, \textit{Food Expenditure}, \textit{Education Expenditure}. \\ The hypotheses tested are: \\ \textbf{E1:} Legal electrification should increase total expenditures, meaning $\beta>0$. \\ \textbf{E2:} Legal electrification should lower expenditures on kerosene,$\beta0$. \subsubsection{Kerosene} We test the effect of legal electrification on two outcome variables: the use of kerosene lamps for lighting, \textit{Kerosene Lamps}, and the use for kerosene for other purposes, \textit{Kerosene General}. \\ %are these the only outcomes to test? The hypotheses tested are: \\ \textbf{K1:} Legal electrification should reduce the use of kerosene lamps, $\beta < 0$. \textbf{K2:} Legal electrification should reduce the use of kerosene for other purposes, $\beta < 0$. \subsubsection{Artificial Lighting} We test two outcomes for artificial lighting: household use of artifical light \textit{Household Light}, adult use of artificial light, \textit{Adult Light}, and use of artificial light by children, \textit{Child Light}. \\ The hypotheses tested are: \\ \textbf{L1:} Legal electrification should increase the hours of artificial light used by households, $\beta > 0$. \\ \textbf{L2:} Legal electrification should increase the hours of artificial light used by adults, $\beta > 0$. \\ \textbf{L3:} Legal electrification should increase the hours of artificial light used by children, $\beta > 0$. \subsubsection{Household Activity} We test two outcomes for household activity: Hours children spend at home, \textit{Child Activity}, and hours adults spend at home, \textit{Adult Activity}. \\ The hypotheses tested are: \\ \textbf{H1:} Legal electrification should increase the hours children spend at home, $\beta >0$. \\ \textbf{H2:} Legal electrification should increase the hours adults spend at home, $\beta > 0$. \subsubsection{Appliances} We test two outcomes for appliances: total number of appliances \textit{Number of Appliances}, and number of hours using appliances \textit{Appliance Use}. \\ The hypotheses tested are: \\ \textbf{A1:} Legal electrification should increase the number of appliances owned by households, $\beta > 0$. \textbf{A2:} Legal electrification should increase the number of hours using appliances by households, $\beta>0$. \subsubsection{Satisfaction and Attitudes} We test eleven outcomes for satisfaction and attitudes. The first variable is satisfaction with the reliability of the primary lighting source \textit{Reliable}, the second is satisfaction with the cost of the primary lighting source \textit{Cost}, and the third is satisfaction with the safety of the primary lighting source \textit{Safety}. The fourth variable is satisfaction with the brightness of the primary lighting source \textit{Brightness}. The fifth is overall satisfaction with lighting \textit{Satisfaction with Lighting}. The sixth is satisfaction with lighting now as compared to 5 years ago, \textit{Change in Satisfaction}. The seventh is the monetary value of further electricity by households, \textit{Value}. The eighth measure is satisfaction with electricity for electrified businesses, \textit{Business Satisfaction}. The ninth is, for unelectrified businesses, whether the owners believe that electrification would increase their business income, \textit{Increase in Income}. We then measure two outcomes for aspirations. The 10th variable is whether a household is interested in starting a new business in the future \textit{Business Aspiration}. The 11th variable is an index of measures of aspirations \textit{General Aspirations}. \\ We have twelve hypotheses for this section: \\ \textbf{S1:} Legal electrification should increase satisfaction with the reliability of lighting, $\beta>0$. \\ \textbf{S2:} Legal electrification should increase satisfaction with the cost of lighting, $\beta>0$. \\ \textbf{S3:} Legal electrification should increase satisfaction with the safety of lighting, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S4:} Legal electrification should increase satisfaction with the brightness of lighting, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S5:} Legal electrification should increase overall satisfaction with lighting, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S6:} Legal electrification should increase changes in satisfaction over the last 5 years, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S7:} Legal electrification should decrease the monetary value of further electricity, $\beta0$.\\ \textbf{S9:} Legal electrification should increase the belief that electrification would increase their business income, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S10:} Legal electrification should increase interest in starting a new business in the future, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S11:} Legal electrification should increase aspirations, $\beta>0$.\\ \subsubsection{General Knowledge} We have one outcome for general knowledge. The variable, \textit{Knowledge}, is a count of the number of correct answers given to the enumerator. \\ We test one hypothesis: \\ \textbf{G1:} Legal electrification should increase general knowledge, $\beta>0$.

q17.value: To examine the relationship between legal electricity connections and several outcomes, we implement a survey in rural Indian habitations. We exploit a law dictating access to legal electrical connections: househoulds within 40 meters of power poles can legally gain electrical access, while those beeyond the 40 meter radius cannot. Thus, we implement a "fuzzy" regression discontinuity design, using distance from the power poles as an instrument for electrification status. \subsection{Sampling} Our unit of sampling is a power pole, selected based on its distance from the center of a habitation. For each given power pole, we record all households within 20 to 35 meters of the pole, and those within 45 to 60 meters of the pole. The distance to the pole is measured by measuring tape. Households are then excluded if they are between the power pole and the village center, or the power pole and a different power pole. This is to prevent overlap with other poles: in the field it was identified that if households are between the pole and the village, there is the potential for poles hidden behind buildings to not be identified by enumerators, and to influence the treatment assignment.

The eighth measure is satisfaction with electricity for electrified businesses, \textit{Business Satisfaction}. The ninth is, for unelectrified businesses, whether the owners believe that electrification would increase their business income, \textit{Increase in Income}. We then measure two outcomes for aspirations. The 10th variable is whether a household is interested in starting a new business in the future \textit{Business Aspiration}. The 11th variable is an index of measures of aspirations \textit{General Aspirations}. \\ We have twelve hypotheses for this section: \\ \textbf{S1:} Legal electrification should increase satisfaction with the reliability of lighting, $\beta>0$. \\ \textbf{S2:} Legal electrification should increase satisfaction with the cost of lighting, $\beta>0$. \\ \textbf{S3:} Legal electrification should increase satisfaction with the safety of lighting, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S4:} Legal electrification should increase satisfaction with the brightness of lighting, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S5:} Legal electrification should increase overall satisfaction with lighting, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S6:} Legal electrification should increase changes in satisfaction over the last 5 years, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S7:} Legal electrification should decrease the monetary value of further electricity, $\beta0$.\\ \textbf{S9:} Legal electrification should increase the belief that electrification would increase their business income, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S10:} Legal electrification should increase interest in starting a new business in the future, $\beta>0$.\\ \textbf{S11:} Legal electrification should increase aspirations, $\beta>0$.\\ \subsubsection{General Knowledge} We have one outcome for general knowledge. The variable, \textit{Knowledge}, is a count of the number of correct answers given to the enumerator. \\ We test one hypothesis: \\ \textbf{G1:} Legal electrification should increase general knowledge, $\beta>0$.
registration_responses.q17: To examine the relationship between legal electricity connections and several outcomes, we implement a survey in rural Indian habitations. We exploit a law dictating access to legal electrical connections: househoulds within 40 meters of power poles can legally gain electrical access, while those beeyond the 40 meter radius cannot. Thus, we implement a "fuzzy" regression discontinuity design, using distance from the power poles as an instrument for electrification status. \subsection{Sampling} Our unit of sampling is a power pole, selected based on its distance from the center of a habitation. For each given power pole, we record all households within 20 to 35 meters of the pole, and those within 45 to 60 meters of the pole. The distance to the pole is measured by measuring tape. Households are then excluded if they are between the power pole and the village center, or the power pole and a different power pole. This is to prevent overlap with other poles: in the field it was identified that if households are between the pole and the village, there is the potential for poles hidden behind buildings to not be identified by enumerators, and to influence the treatment assignment.
